addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

xj N
o
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
The Dowbtfulnes of
e
states
to make conference to
e Empero
rs
Deputies.
Copie of a l
re
he would write (w
th
hir
Ma
ties
allowance) to
em./.

page.lettertext:
fol.194r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have sent yo
w
very lately
e copies of all suche letters, as
have passed between
e states and
e Empero
rs
Commissioners. And sins I have heard no more,
but that whiche I writte
e 6 of this moneth,
that they had sent to
e
D. of Parma
, for a Con-
voy of 3 Cornets of horse, to conduct them to
Brussels.
Astouching that treaty whiche
is required by
e
Empero
r
,
as I have alwaies
written to yo
r
L. If it be possible for me to
see into
e mindes and dispositions of the
states, or of
e
Councel,
or of any in general
of
e Commons of these Provinces, they have
not onely no affection to hearcken unto it, but
they are passionatly bent to oppose against it.
onely one thing, I doe see, doth trouble them
muche, howe to finde a fitte excuse, to stoppe
e course of those Ambassado
rs
for comming
further onward. For first, they thinke,
they will pretend some other causes of their
comming, then to motion a Pacification:
and then againe they are persuaded, that all
Ambassado
rs
,
iure gentium
, ought to be ad-
mitted w
t
out any impeachement: and thirdly
there hath bin alwaies a freedome of enter-
course, betweene
e inhabitants heere and
those of
e Empire. So
at if they be rejected,
it may putte them heere in danger of
e Bande
of
e Empire: of whiche, me thinkes, they are
affraide, in regard of their trafficke.
fol.194v
I finde for these occasions
at they stagger in
their Counsailes: for w
ch
I have moved them
of late, to addresse an other letter to
e forsaid
Commissioners, and besides their former allega-
tions, to acquaint them w
t
e Contract (whiche
hitherto they have not) between her Ma
tie
and
e
contrey, by whiche they doe stipulat, not to deale
w
t
e Spaniard, or w
t
any other Prince, by way of
treaty or accord, w
t
out her Ma
ties
assent. W
t
all
to signifie unto them,
at forasmuche as these Pro-
vinces are full of Martiall people of her Ma
ties
subjectes, who are all of them bounde by their
othe and alleagance, to maintene and cause to
be maintened every article of
e Contract:
by reason therof unles they come w
t
some war-
rant from her Ma
tie
of
England,
they can not
heere undertake to protect their persons from
e violence and outrage of those of
e Englishe
nation. This was well enough liked by
e Councel and
Count Maurice
, and thought
a ready meanes to cutte them of from procee-
ding in their purposed voiage: and that w
t
out
any prejudice to themselves or to
e Contrey.
Howbeit when
e advise was required of the
Deputies heere of
e g
nr
al states, they were lothe
to hearcken to it: alleaging nothing to
e purpose,
but
at they would reserve that course of pro-
ceeding for a better opportunitie. But as farre
as I can conjecture, they are inwardly afraid
that if
e Ambassado
rs
threupon should seeke
unto her Ma
tie
they might finde their audience
fol.195r
and accesse more easie and favorable, then
they perhaps heere would willingly have it.
For mine owne part, though I see they are Ene-
mies to
e treaty of Peace, yet because I have
not
e best opinion of their Constancie, for w
t
-
standing their entrance, and becauess I thinke
her Hig
nes
is utterly against it, I have thought
upon a way, w
ch
if yo
r
L. shall approve, I
would humbly desire that is might be imparted,
and her Ma
ties
pleasure declared unto me.
It is a letter from my self to
e Empero
rs
Am-
bassado
rs
, written to suche purpose, as I wished
had bin done from
e assembly of
e states, but
w
t
many more additions, and suche as are material
to my
utte
understanding: thought it may be not
so pleasing to
e humo
r
of this people: for whiche
I have not shewed it heere to any. Nevertheles
because there is nothing in it prejudicial unto
them, and her Ma
tie
me thinkes, may be served
by it, as yo
r
L. shall direct me I will ether
send it, or suppresse it: attending from yo
w
in that behalf yo
r
speedy resolution.
And so
so I take my humble leave. At
e Hage.
N
o
11 1591.
Yo
r
L . most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
If her Ma
tie
be pleased
at I shall
send
e forsaid letter, I will putte
it into Frenche, and impart it heere
unto
e Councel: and whether they
like it, or otherwise, I will send
it presently away.
